seo.title: EC & TDS Explained: Water Conductivity Measurement
seo.description: Understanding electrical conductivity (EC) and total dissolved solids (TDS) in water: what they measure, how to interpret readings, and what affects them.

sections.html:
Zone 2 • Measurement

EC/TDS in Water

Conductivity Basics — What's In Your Water

EC (Electrical Conductivity) and TDS (Total Dissolved Solids) tell you how many ions are dissolved in water.

What EC/TDS Measures

  • EC (μS/cm) — how well water conducts electricity
  • TDS (ppm) — estimated dissolved solids (EC × conversion factor)

Higher readings = more dissolved ions. This includes minerals, salts, and other charged particles.

Typical Ranges

Common Waters

  • Distilled: 0-10 ppm
  • RO water: 10-50 ppm
  • Tap water: 100-500 ppm
  • Mineral water: 200-800 ppm
  • Sea water: 35,000+ ppm

Andara Dilutions

  • Concentrate: Very high (1000+)
  • Typical use: Depends on dilution and base water

How to Measure

  1. Calibrate meter with calibration solution
  2. Rinse probe with sample water
  3. Submerge probe fully
  4. Wait for reading to stabilize
  5. Record temperature (affects reading)
Get Equipment →

ORP

pH

Tracking

items.question: Is higher TDS better?
items.answer: Not necessarily. It depends on what's dissolved. Beneficial minerals increase TDS, but so do contaminants.

items.question: Why does temperature matter?
items.answer: Conductivity increases with temperature. Most meters auto-compensate, but note the temp anyway.
